The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Symmetric Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Center to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of the Center of a group is defined as the set of all elements in a group $G$ that commute with every other element in $G$. This definition is self-contained and does not inherently require the concept of a Symmetric Group. The Center can be defined for any group, regardless of whether that group is symmetric or not. The Symmetric Group is a specific type of group, one of many possible groups, and is not necessary to understand or define the concept of the Center of a group. The definition of the Center is applicable to any group, including but not limited to Symmetric Groups. Therefore, the concept of a Symmetric Group is not needed to define or understand the concept of the Center of a group.
